headline: Classic Blueberry Muffins Recipe

author.name: Stella Parks
author.description: Stella Parks is a CIA-trained baking nerd and pastry wizard, dubbed one of America's Best New Pastry Chefs by Food & Wine. She was the pastry editor at Serious Eats from 2016 to 2019.

description: The perfect blueberry muffin is quick and easy to whip up on a Sunday morning, and beautiful to behold: domed and delicately crisp on top, with or without a crust of sparkling sugar. Most of all, it's loaded with the best summer berries—which should never, ever sink to the bottom.

video.description: A lot of blueberry muffin recipes tell you to toss the berries in flour first to prevent them from sinking to the bottom of the batter. That doesn't work. Here's a method that does. [Video: Natalie Holt. Technique: Stella Parks]
video.name: A Quick Tip to Make Your Blueberry Muffins Better

name: Classic Blueberry Muffins Recipe
recipeIngredient: 3/4 teaspoon (3g) Diamond Crystal kosher salt; for table salt, use half as much by volume or use the same weight
6 ounces unsalted butter (1 1/2 sticks; 170g), cut into 1/2-inch cubes

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat to 350°F (180°C). Prepare a nonstick or aluminum muffin pan by greasing lightly or lining with tinfoil or paper liners. Combine flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, baking soda, coriander, nutmeg, and butter in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Mix at low speed to form a mealy powder, about 2 minutes. Add milk, eggs, and vanilla (if using), mixing briefly to form a thick batter.

Drop a heaping tablespoonful (about 1 ounce, or 28g if you want to be mathematically precise) of plain dough into the bottom of each muffin cup. Fold blueberries into remaining dough, which will be extremely stiff. Divide evenly between each cup. If you like, top each muffin with sparkling sugar, about 1 teaspoon each or to taste. Bake until muffins are puffed and firm, about 25 minutes. Enjoy immediately and store leftovers in an airtight container for up to 1 day.

review.reviewBody: This is one of my favorite go-tos... it's really resilient to my screwups. It's best when made as written, but once I accidentally added an extra half stick of butter, and once I accidentally doubled the number of eggs-- and both times the muffins came out different, but still tasty. I bought muffin tins for this recipe and I've never regretted that for a moment.

Came out way too stiff for me - cookie dough, rather than "batter". 

"Folding in " in the blueberries was completely out of the question. Best I could do was sort of dump them on top and hope they found their own way in.

Great muffins! I usually make cook's illustrated blueberry muffins or smitten kitchen's adaptation of that recipe, but I was out of sour cream and yogurt, so thought I would try Stella's. It definitely registered more muffin/less cake-like than those two recipes. I also liked the extra buttery flavor. I missed, however, the moisture yogurt or sour cream add. So I think I would make these if I knew all would be eaten immediately (while warm), and use one of the other recipes if I needed them to last more than an hour or two.

I just made these. I used a non-stick muffin pan with cooking spray. I made the muffins as written & confess to adding the zest of a very sad looking lemon. When it came to the blueberries, my frozen stash only had about 1.5 cups, so I reached into a box of very sad fresh berries, and threw maybe 3/4 of a cup in. So I did have too many berries, but in my book, that's not a real problem. I had trouble guaging when they were done...some crumb stuck to the wooden skewer I was using to test doneness, so I also looked for a light brown ring around the muffin. Mine went for 29 minutes. I love the super light (nearly cakey) texture, and the flavor is awesome. Personally, I think I'd like a bit more lemon accent, but the muffins are fantastic.

Too eggy...that's why some complain of a dry muffin..eggs dry out baked goods...also eggs also add egg flavor..I actually love eggless blueberry muffins...the bluberries end up more pronounced in flavor..and moister muffins.
